releases.details: Released in the United Kingdom and Australia, and in the US in 1996

notes: The story was influenced by the film Invasion of the Body Snatchers.
Last appearances of John Benton and Harry Sullivan in the classic series.
Originally, the Kraal androids were to be mirror images of the people they imitated.
Terry Nation's final story in four years, next was Destiny of the Daleks (1979).
The Fourth Doctor's rarely seen light grey tweed coat appeared.
Tom Baker submerged himself during filming, leading to a minor injury.

in_universe_mythology: Styggron plans to use a virus to cleanse the Earth of human life.
The Kraal planet Oseidon has increasing radiation levels.
The androids duplicate individuals for training purposes.
real_world_cultural_references: The Doctor claims he 'always told Alexander Bell that wires were unreliable'.
Story inspired by Invasion of the Body Snatchers.
items: Pattern analyser for android memory and intelligence.
Artificial ivy developed by the Kraals.
Robot detector carried by the Doctor.

continuity_notes: The Space Defence Station in Devesham was later bought by Campbell Irons.
The Doctor mentioned ginger beer a preference in other stories.
Guy Crayford believed the Doctor to be human, a common mistake.
First UNIT story without Nicholas Courtney as Brigadier.
The Doctor has been duplicated several times.

plot.plot_summary: The Doctor and Sarah Jane land near the village of Devesham in 1980. They discover the place is deserted with strange occurrences. They encounter android duplicates of villagers and UNIT soldiers. The duplicates are part of a Kraal invasion plot using androids created to invade Earth after a devastating virus kills its inhabitants. The Doctor and Sarah thwart the plan by using radar to disable the androids while surviving a dangerous race against time to stop the invasion.
